metadata.title: CVE-2024-26826 on Ubuntu 22.04 LTS (jammy) - medium
metadata.description:
In the Linux kernel, the following vulnerability has been resolved: mptcp:fix data re-injection from stale subflow When the MPTCP PM detects that asubflow is stale, all the packet scheduler must re-inject all themptcp-level unacked data. To avoid acquiring unneeded locks, it first tryto check if any unacked data is present at all in the RTX queue, but suchcheck is currently broken, as it uses TCP-specific helper on an MPTCPsocket. Funnily enough fuzzers and static checkers are happy, as theaccessed memory still belongs to the mptcp_sock struct, and even from afunctional perspective the recovery completed successfully, as theshort-cut test always failed. A recent unrelated TCP change - commitd5fed5addb2b ("tcp: reorganize tcp_sock fast path variables") - exposed theissue, as the tcp field reorganization makes the mptcp code always skip there-inection. Fix the issue dropping the bogus call: we are on a slow path,the early optimization proved once again to be evil.

    Update Instructions:

    Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2024-26826` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
    by updating your system to the following package versions:

linux-image-5.15.0-106-generic - 5.15.0-106.116
linux-image-5.15.0-106-generic-lpae - 5.15.0-106.116
linux-image-unsigned-5.15.0-106-generic - 5.15.0-106.116
linux-image-unsigned-5.15.0-106-generic-64k - 5.15.0-106.116
No subscription required

linux-image-unsigned-5.15.0-1058-kvm - 5.15.0-1058.63
No subscription required

linux-image-unsigned-5.15.0-1061-aws - 5.15.0-1061.67
No subscription required

No subscription required

No subscription required

No subscription required

No subscription required

No subscription required

No subscription required

criterions.comment: linux package in jammy was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '5.15.0-106.116').
